sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Find the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 - 5, given an initial guess of x0 = 2, using the Newton-Raphson method up to three iterations.
message_2:
To apply the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 - 5. 

The derivative f'(x) = 3x^2 - 4x.

Now, we will perform three iterations of the Newton-Raphson method using the initial guess x0 = 2.

Iteration 1:
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)
x1 = 2 - (2^3 - 2(2^2) - 5) / (3(2^2) - 4(2))
x1 = 2 - (8 - 8 - 5) / (12 - 8)
x1 = 2 - (-5) / 4
x1 = 2 + 5/4
x1 = 9/4

Iteration 2:
x2 = x1 - f(x1) / f'(x1)
x2 = 9/4 - ((9/4)^3 - 2(9/4)^2 - 5) / (3(9/4)^2 - 4(9/4))
x2 ≈ 2.2058823529411766

Iteration 3:
x3 = x2 - f(x2) / f'(x2)
x3 ≈ 2.2058823529411766 - ((2.2058823529411766)^3 - 2(2.2058823529411766)^2 - 5) / (3(2.2058823529411766)^2 - 4(2.2058823529411766))
x3 ≈ 2.0952380952380953

After three iterations of the Newton-Raphson method, we have an approximate root of x ≈ 2.0952380952380953.
